journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Using overflow in a swash plate compressor for automotive air conditioning system

article-meta.aff: Institute of Refrigeration and Cryogenics, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *Institute of Refrigeration and Cryogenics, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Road, Shanghai 200240, People’s Republic of China. email: wenwang@sjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Given current environment protection problems, improvement of energy utilization efficiency is a major focus of compressor research. Overflow, a method in which the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume is fully used, is introduced in the design of a swash plate compressor. The coefficient of performance (COP) of the swash plate compressor with overflow channel has a certain decrease compared with the conventional compressor, but the volumetric efficiency and the cooling capacity of a swash plate compressor with overflow channel are visibly more improved than those of a conventional compressor in terms of the same operation and dimension parameters. The overflow has beneficial effect on miniaturizing the swash plate compressor. The intake and exhaust times considerably improve after the overflow channel is incorporated into the swash plate compressor. This, in turn, substantially enhances cooling capacity of the theoretical results from 869 to 953 W, an improvement by about 10 per cent in this article; however, COP decreases by about 3.7 per cent.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Automotive air conditioning has undergone significant global advancements with the rapid development of the auto-industry, which has some features such as large thermal load variations, comfort, compactness, and high efficiency. The variable displacement compressor is the compressor of choice in automotive air conditioning systems, because it satisfies the various demands of an automotive air conditioning system through changes in piston stroke length [1, 2]. As a variable displacement reciprocating compressor, the swash plate compressor is increasingly used more often because of its simple structure, low noise, and excellent performance. Taya et al. [3] and Miyagawa and Kayukawa [4] presented the structure, principle, and mechanism of a swash plate-type variable displacement compressor. Tian et al. [5] and Yuan and Chen [6] developed a steady-state mathematical model of this type of unit. Lee et al. [7] carried out the performance analyses of separate components of an automobile air conditioning system (includes a swash plate-type compressor) under various operating conditions. Tian et al. [5, 8–10] established a test bench for the variable displacement swash plate compressor (VDSC) and the test system for automotive air conditioner with VDSC, the volumetric efficiency, the piston stroke length and displacement control, and transient behaviour along with air conditioning load or compressor rotary speed are experimentally investigated, and the simulated results agree well with the experimental data.

Given current environmental protection problems and the increasing price of gasoline, developing more efficient automotive air conditioning systems and implementing improvements in the efficiency of swash plate compressors are necessary initial steps. Relevant studies on swash plate compressors are rare. To this end, this article focuses on improving the efficiency of a swash plate compressor.

The clearance volume of a swash plate compressor is the sum of the volume between the piston and the cylinder bottom at the end of the exhaust process and the volume of the channel between the cylinder bottom and the valve. The existence of the clearance volume in a swash plate compressor is inevitable primarily because of liquid hammer and piston knock avoidance. In general, the clearance volume makes up about 3–8 per cent of cylinder volume and approximately 5–12 per cent of the compressor with a high working pressure and small cylinder diameter. Volumetric efficiency and cylinder displacement are reduced to a great extent because of the existence of the clearance volume. Therefore, improving the performance of a swash plate compressor entails two methods: reducing the clearance volume and fully using the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume. Based on the analysis above, the issue of clearance volume is unavoidable in the design of a swash plate compressor. Thus, one can focus on making full use of the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume to improve performance.

The multi-cylinder swash plate compressors include odd cylinders and even cylinders compressor, and the odd number of cylinders normally are adopted in practice as this reduces the torque fluctuations and noise compared to an even cylinders compressor. On the basis of simplifying the theoretical analysis, the twin cylinder swash plate compressor has been used to analysis the potential making full use of the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume to improve compressor’s performance.

The twin cylinder swash plate compressor has two cylinders, with one of the cylinders functioning at the end of the exhaust process and the other functioning at the initial stage of the compression process. At this time, the gas pressure in the exhaust cylinder (that is, the clearance volume) is visibly higher than that in the compression cylinder. The high-pressure gas in the clearance volume flows into the compression cylinder by a certain mechanism; this flow can considerably improve the pressure in the compression cylinder and decrease that in the clearance volume. Therefore, swash plate compressor performance can be substantially enhanced as well. An A3 overflow channel is adopted to achieve the above-mentioned mixing process (Fig. 1(b)). The concept of overflow in a Wankel compressor was put forward by Dankwart in 1984 [11], but correlative analysis and the reasonable use of the compressor have never been discussed in current literature. Fig. 1
Schematic of a swash plate compressor: (a) conventional swash plate compressor and (b) swash plate compressor with an overflow channel

The overflow design is introduced for improving the swash plate compressor performance. The corresponding performance levels are analysed in detail by thermodynamics and computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations. The theoretical equations of volumetric efficiency, cylinder displacement, and coefficient of performance (COP) are comprehensively deduced, and the influencing factors are analysed in detail. The state parameters in the clearance volume and compression cylinder after overflow has occurred are also examined. Finally, contrast analysis between the theoretical and simulation results is conducted.

sec.title: 2 OVERFLOW IN A SWASH PLATE COMPRESSOR
2.1 Performance of the conventional swash plate compressor
sec.p:
The sequence 1–2–3–4–1 represents the thermal process of a conventional swash plate compressor (Fig. 2). The compression, exhaust, expansion, and intake processes correspond to sequences 1–2, 2–3, 3–4, and 4–1, respectively. The expansion and compression processes of a conventional swash plate compressor are assumed to be polytropic and have the same polytropic exponent. Two main factors are used in evaluating compressor performance: volumetric efficiency and cylinder displacement. In this study, the performance analysis of the swash plate compressor is carried out with respect to these two factors. Fig. 2
P–V diagram of the thermal process of a even cylinders swash plate compressor

sec.title: 2.1.1 Volumetric efficiency
sec.p: The volumetric efficiency of a compressor is expressed by the ratio of inspiratory capacity (Ve) to stroke volume (Vh). Inspiratory capacity refers to the difference between the maximum volume and expansion cylinder volume when gas pressure expands to intake pressure. Stroke volume pertains to the difference between the maximum and minimum volumes of the working cylinder. The volumetric efficiency of a conventional swash plate compressor is calculated by (1) For a swash plate compressor, the relative clearance volume can be calculated by the following equations (2)

According to the assumption that the expansion process (corresponding to lines 3–4) and the compression process (corresponding to lines 1–2) are polytropic processes and have the same exponent, one can have (3) Equations (2) and (3) are substituted into equation (1). The volumetric efficiency of a swash plate compressor can be expressed by (4)

sec.title: 2.1.2 Cylinder displacement
sec.p: The cylinder displacement of a compressor is calculated by the difference between the volume of the compression cylinder at the end of the compression process and the volume of the exhaust cylinder at the end of the exhaust process. As shown in Fig. 2, the cylinder displacement of a compressor can be obtained by (5) where β=V3V1=τ1+τ

sec.title: 2.1.3 Coefficient of performance
sec.p: According to Fig. 2, the net work of a compressor (WC) is obtained by (6) The cooling capacity of a vapour compression refrigeration cycle employing such a compressor can be calculated by (7) The COP of a cooling cycle with a conventional swash plate compressor can be shown by the ratio of the cooling capacity q and the power consumption WC (8)

sec.title: 2.2 Thermal process in the swash plate compressor with overflow
sec.p: Making full use of the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume is an effective method in improving the performance of a swash plate compressor. For a conventional unit, the expansion process of the gas in the clearance volume is an expansion process approximately adiabatically. The gas pressure in the clearance volume continuously decreases with increasing volume until the gas pressure reaches the point of intake pressure and the compressor turns into the intake process. Therefore, the existence of the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume reduces inspiratory capacity, resulting in a corresponding decline in performance.

The performance of a swash plate compressor can be considerably improved by fully using the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume. At the end of the exhaust process, the exhaust and intake valves are shut, and the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume flows into the compression cylinder with the low-pressure gas through the overflow channel. This results in a rapid drop in the gas pressure in the clearance volume, and a significant increase in the gas pressure in the compression cylinder. The mixing process is assumed to occur instantaneously.

Sequence 1–1′–2′–3–3′–4′–1 shows the detailed thermal process of the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel shown in Fig. 2. The line from points 1 to 1′ represents the mixing process that results in the rapid rise in pressure through the overflow channel. The compression process of the mixed gas and exhaust process are illustrated with lines 1′–2′ and 2′–3, respectively. Point 3 represents the gas state at the end of the exhaust process, at which time the exhaust valve is shut and overflow begins. Thus, the gas pressure in the clearance volume rapidly drops, as illustrated by line 3–3′ The extent of change in gas pressure in the clearance volume is substantially larger than that in the compression chamber because the volume of the compression cylinder is much larger than the clearance volume when overflow occurs. Profiles 3′–4′ and 4′1 show the expansion and intake processes, respectively. The comparison of the thermal processes of a conventional swash plate compressor and a swash plate compressor with overflow shows that after incorporating an overflow channel into the compressor, the cylinder volume at the beginning of the exhaust process visibly increases, and the cylinder volume at the beginning of the intake process noticeably decreases. Therefore, inspiratory capacity and cylinder displacement, as well as performance, are considerably enhanced as well.

sec.title: 2.3 Performance of the swash plate compressor with overflow
2.3.1 State parameter of mixed gas
sec.p:
On the basis of the analysis above, the overflow channel design is adopted to improve the performance of the swash plate compressor. The gas between the clearance volume and compression cylinder is assumed to be well mixed by the overflow channel. The mixing process is shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3
Schematic of the mixing process through the overflow channel

Before overflow occurs, the main gas state parameters in the clearance volume (a) and compression cylinder (b) are P3, T3, V3 and P1, T1, V1, respectively. After overflow occurs, the gas state parameters are assumed to be Pm, Tm, and Vm, and the state parameters of point 1′ are the same as those of point 3′ (Fig. 2), because the gases are assumed to be well mixed. Therefore, Pm = P1′ = P3′, Tm = T1′ = T3′, and Vm = V1 + V3.

The mixing process is assumed to be adiabatic, and no energy exchange with the external environment occurs. Therefore, the internal energy remains unchanged during the mixing process on the basis of the first law of thermodynamics; that is, ΔU = 0 (9) (10)

The gas temperature relatively exhibits small change during the mixing process. Thus, molar heat capacity can be taken as an approximately fixed value; that is, CV,m,A = CV,m,B. The temperature and pressure of mixed gas can be calculated by (11) (12)

sec.title: 2.3.2 Volumetric efficiency
sec.p: After adopting the overflow design in the swash plate compressor, the cylinder volume (V4′) at the beginning of the intake process is visibly smaller than that (V4) in the conventional compressor (Fig. 2). Therefore, the inspiratory capacity (Ve) of the swash plate compressor with overflow noticeably expands compared with that of the conventional compressor. The corresponding volumetric efficiency is expressed as (13)

The expansion process of the mixed gas in the clearance volume and the compression process of the mixed gas in the compression cylinder are assumed to be polytropic. The overflow process is assumed to be instantaneous and well mixed. Hence, V3 = V3′, V1 = V1′, and P3′ = P1′ (14)
The volumetric efficiency of the swash plate compressor with overflow can be obtained using equations (2) and (12) to (14) (15) where ϕ=βγ+1β+1

sec.title: 2.3.3 Cylinder displacement
sec.p: The cylinder displacement of the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel can be obtained by (16) where V2′ is the cylinder volume of the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel at the beginning of the exhaust process; this volume is larger than that (V2) of the conventional compressor. Thus, the cylinder displacement is considerably improved because of the incorporation of the overflow channel into the design of the swash plate compressor.
The cylinder displacement of the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel can be obtained using equations (2), (12), (14), and (16) (17)

sec.title: 2.3.4 Coefficient of performance
sec.p: According to Fig. 2, the net work of the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel (WC ') can be calculated as below (18) The cooling capacity of a vapour compression refrigeration cycle employing such a compressor and the COP are expressed as (19) (20) The ratio of cycle COPs with the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel and the conventional swash plate compressor respectively (21)

sec.title: 2.3.5 Overflow rate
sec.p: The results above are obtained under the premise that the mixing process is fully achieved through the overflow channel; in actual operations; however, the mixing process may not be complete. To describe the degree of completion of the overflow process, the overflow rate is presented in this article. The clearance volume (V3) is assumed to be divided into two parts, namely, V31 and V32. During overflow, only the high-pressure gas in V31 mixes with the low-pressure gas in the compression cylinder. The gas pressure in V32 remains unchanged. Therefore, the overflow rate is expressed as (22)
According to equation (12), the mixed gas pressure in the compression cylinder and clearance volume can be shown as (23) (24)
According to equations (22) to (24), the mixed gas pressure in the clearance volume when the overflow rate is λ can be calculated by (25)

The corresponding volumetric efficiency, the displacement of cylinder, the ratio of COP between the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel, and the conventional swash plate compressor are expressed as (26) (27) (28) where φ=γλ(β-1)+γ+λ1+λβ, ψ=γλβ+1λβ+1
On the basis of equations (4), (5), (15), (17), (21), and (26) to (28), the following conclusions are drawn.

The volumetric efficiency and the ratio of COP between the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel and the conventional swash plate compressor is related only to the compression ratio (γ) and the relative clearance volume (τ). Aside from these, the factors influencing the cylinder displacement of the swash plate compressor are also related to length (L) and diameter (D). The overflow rate (λ) should be considered in analysing volumetric efficiency, cylinder displacement, and COP if the mixing process is not sufficiently complete.

sec.title: 2.3.6 Overflow in the odd cylinders swash plate compressor
sec.p:
With odd cylinders in a swash plate compressor, when an exhaust chamber reaches the minimum there is a chamber in the initial stage of the compression process. The thermal process of overflow has been shown in Fig. 4. The 1–1″–1′–2′–3–3′–4′–1 process illustrates the thermodynamic cycle of an odd cylinder compressor with overflow. Lines 1–1″ and 1′–2′ are the compression processes, and 1″–1′ represents the process of the pressure rapidly rising by overflow. Lines 3–3′ and 3′–4′ illustrate the rapid pressure reduction and expansion processes, respectively. The difference of the points 2′ and 4′ of the odd cylinders swash plate compressor with overflow and the points 2 and 4 of the conventional swash plate compressor shows the effect of overflow, that is, the inspiratory capacity and cylinder displacement, as well as volumetric efficiency and cooling capacity, are considerably enhanced after incorporating an overflow channel into the swash plate compressor. Fig. 4
The P–V diagram of a odd cylinder swash plate compressor thermodynamic cycle

The overflow channels could be placed easily if the cylinder number was even. While there were 5 or 7, odd number cylinders, the overflow could be applied still, e.g. the overflow passages have been placed in the main shaft, and which rotate and fit with the status of the cylinders (as shown in Fig. 5). Therefore, the higher pressure gas in the clearance volume can flow into the opposite cylinder at the initial stage of compression process by the overflow passage. Only one overflow passage has been placed in the design of multi-cylinder compressor, whether it is for odd cylinders compressor or even cylinders compressor, because the channel in the main shaft and the different cylinders (the cylinder at the end of exhaust process and that at the initial stage of compression process) have been connected with the rotating of main shaft. One difficulty in above design is the seal, the seal between the side face of main shaft and the internal surface of cylinder and that between the top face of main shaft and outside are controlled by the machining accuracy and the shaft seal respectively. Therefore, for incorporating the overflow channel into compressor, it is necessary to improve the machining accuracy and shaft seal. Fig. 5
The overflow channel sketch of seven-cylinder compressor: (a) assembly drawing, (b) cylinder, and (c) main shaft with overflow

sec.title: 2.4 Results and discussion
sec.p:
According to the analysis above, the volumetric efficiency of the swash plate compressor is related only to the compression ratio and the relative clearance volume. Variations in the volumetric efficiency at different compression ratios and relative clearance volume are shown in Fig. 6. Fig. 6
Variations in the volumetric efficiency at (a) different compression ratios and (b) different relative clearance volumes

Assuming that the relative clearance volume is about 3.125 per cent, the volumetric efficiency gradually decreases with the increase in compression ratio whether or not the overflow channel is incorporated into the swash plate compressor [Fig. 6(a)]. The volumetric efficiency of the compressor with an overflow channel is visibly higher than that of the conventional compressor. This difference continuously increases with increasing compression ratio. The volumetric efficiency of the compressor with an overflow channel is nearly higher than 99.5 per cent at compression ratios of 1:8. The corresponding volumetric efficiency of the conventional compressor rapidly drops to approximately 88 per cent.

Variations in the volumetric efficiency of the swash plate compressor at different relative clearance volumes are shown in Fig. 6(b), with the compression ratio set to 5. Within the range [1%, 15%] of the relative clearance volume, the volumetric efficiency of the compressor with an overflow channel slightly declines and is maintained at nearly above 95 per cent. However, that of the conventional compressor rapidly drops to approximately 65 per cent from about 97 per cent.

The analysis results show that the overflow design has a considerable effect on the volumetric efficiency of the swash plate compressor, especially at a large compression ratio or relative clearance volume.

On the basis of the same dimensions (the diameter and length of the cylinder are approximately 20 and 16.5 mm, respectively), Figs 7(a) and 8(a) show the variations in the cylinder displacement and the increasing percentage of cylinder displacement before and after overflow design in the swash plate compressor at different compression ratios, and when the relative clearance volume is 3.125 per cent. Figures 7(b) and 8(b) show the variations at different relative clearance volume when the compressor ratio is 5. All the cylinder displacements exhibit a certain decline with increasing compression ratio or relative clearance volume. The cylinder displacement of the compressor with overflow is visibly larger than that of the conventional compressor. The increasing percentage of the cylinder displacement caused by the overflow continuously increases with increasing compression ratio or relative clearance volume (Fig. 8). Fig. 7
Variations in the cylinder displacement at (a) different compression ratios and (b) different relative clearance volumes Fig. 8
Increasing percentage of cylinder displacement by the overflow design at (a) different compression ratios and (b) different relative clearance volumes

Figure 9 illustrates the effect of the overflow rate on swash plate compressor performance under the same parameters (the diameter and length of the cylinder are approximately 20 and 16.5 mm, respectively; the compression ratio is 5 and the relative clearance volume 3.125 per cent). The volumetric efficiency and cylinder displacement grow almost linearly with increasing overflow rate. Overflow does not occur when the overflow rate is 0, at which time the volumetric efficiency and cylinder displacement are about 92.6 per cent and 1020 mm3, respectively. When the overflow rate is 100 per cent, the high-pressure gas in the clearance volume mixes well with the low-pressure gas in the compression cylinder of the swash plate compressor. The volumetric efficiency and cylinder displacement improve by approximately 7–99.7 per cent and by about 10 per cent to 1120 mm3, respectively. Fig. 9
Variations in the volumetric efficiency and cylinder displacement at different overflow rates

Figures 10 to 12 show the effect of overflow on the COP. The ratio of COP between the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel and the conventional compressor decreases with the increasing compression ratio, relative clearance volume, and overflow rate. The COP decreases by about 3.7 per cent when compression ratio and relative clearance volume are 5 and 3.125 per cent, respectively. Fig. 10
Variation in the ratio of COP between the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel and the conventional compressor at different compression ratios Fig. 11
Variation in the ratio of COP between the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel and the conventional compressor at different relative clearance volumes Fig. 12
Variation in the ratio of COP between the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel and the conventional compressor at different overflow rates

After setting overflow channel in a conventional swash plate compressor, the volumetric efficiency and cylinder displacement significantly increased. But the COP has a slight decrease, and whose variance amplitudes are smaller than those of volumetric efficiency and cylinder displacement. The cooling capacity of the swash plate compressor with overflow channel is larger than the conventional compressor in terms of the same operation and dimension parameters, and the swash plate compressor with overflow channel is more compact than the conventional compressor on the basis of the same designed parameters. The overflow has beneficial effect on miniaturizing the swash plate compressor.

sec.title: 3 VARIATIONS IN STATE PARAMETERS CAUSED BY OVERFLOW IN THE SWASH PLATE COMPRESSOR
3.1 Overflow velocity at the overflow channel of the swash plate compressor
sec.p:
To generate a complete effect of overflow on the swash plate compressor and the overflow process in the shortest time possible, the overflow channel should be designed in the clearance volume. The schematic of the overflow design is shown in Fig. 13. The high-pressure (1) and low-pressure (2) cylinders are connected by the overflow channel (3). Fig. 13
Schematic of overflow

The energy equation for steady flow is (29) where wi represents the work of working fluid, and includes the energy loss resulting from viscous loss (wvis) and the inertia work (win) (30) The energy loss resulting from viscous loss (wvis) can be shown as (31)

According to Fig. 13, the local resistance coefficient consists of sudden contraction (ζ1) and sudden enlargement (ζ2), where (32) The inertia work (win) can be calculated by (33) Assuming that the cross-section is uniform everywhere in the overflow recesses, the velocity at the overflow recesses is also equal everywhere on the basis of the continuity equation. Thus, the work caused by inertia resulting from the unsteady flow is (34) The steady flow energy equation can be shown as (35) To satisfy the demands of actual applications, the equation should be further simplified based on the following assumptions.
The variation of potential energy has no significant contribution in the compressor cycle, thus, z1 = z2.
The on-way resistance loss is relatively small compared with the local resistance loss in the overflow process of the swash plate compressor. Therefore, the on-way resistance loss can be disregarded.
The cross-section of the overflow channel is very small relative to the cross-sections of the other two cylinders. Therefore, the local resistance coefficient of sudden contraction is ζ1 = 0.5 and that of sudden enlargement is ζ2 = 1.0.
The overflow velocity is much larger than the velocity in the cylinders connected by the overflow channel. Thus, the velocity before and after the overflow channel is incorporated and is assumed to be 0; that is, v1 = v2 = 0.
The overflow time is very short, so that the clearance volume and the volume of the compression cylinder are assumed to be unchanged.
According to these assumptions, Bernoulli’s equation can be simplified to (36) The discrete equation is (37) The overflow velocity can be calculated by (38)

sec.title: 3.2 Results and discussion
sec.p:
The results of the analysis of the overflow effect on the state parameters of the working cylinder in the swash plate compressor are shown in Figs 14 to 17. The results are obtained based on the same parameters (cylinder diameter and length, approximately 20 and 16.5 mm, respectively; compression ratio, 5; relative clearance volume, 3.125 per cent). The overflow time and the maximum velocity at the overflow channel gradually decline with increasing cross-section area of overflow channel. At the end of overflow, the gas pressure and temperature in the compression cylinder continuously rise with increasing cross-section area of overflow channel; the variations in the clearance volume show an opposite trend. The extent of increase and decrease in gas pressure and temperature is relatively small because overflow is assumed to be complete. Figure 16 shows gas pressure variations in the compression cylinder and clearance volume during the overflow time when the cross-section area of overflow channel is approximately 8 mm2. The pressure difference continuously declines. At the end of the overflow process, the gas pressure in the compression cylinder is almost higher than that in the clearance volume because of the inertial force in equation (35), except for the 2 mm2 of the cross-section area of overflow channel because of the relatively larger flow resistance losses resulted from the higher overflow velocity and the smaller cross-section area of overflow channel. The pressure difference, which gradually increases with increasing cross-section area of overflow channel, is illustrated in Fig. 17. Fig. 14
Variations in the overflow time and maximum overflow velocity with different cross-section areas of overflow channel Fig. 15
Variations in gas pressure and temperature at the end of overflow at different cross-section areas of overflow channel: (a) compression cylinder and (b) clearance volume Fig. 16
Variations in gas pressure during the overflow time Fig. 17
Variations in the pressure difference between the compression cylinder and the clearance volume at the end of overflow at different cross-section areas of overflow channel

sec.title: 4 SIMULATION OF THE EFFECT OF OVERFLOW ON THE PERFORMANCE OF THE SWASH PLATE COMPRESSOR
4.1 Initial conditions of the compressor
sec.p:
The effect of overflow on the performance of a twin cylinder swash plate compressor is also analysed by CFD. The operational conditions and dimensions of the swash plate compressor are shown in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. Table 1
Operational conditions of the twin cylinder swash plate compressor with the refrigerant R134a
No. Parameter Description Unit Value
1 Q Cooling capacity W 800
2 n Motor speed n/min 2000
3 Teva Evaporation temperature °C 5
4 Tcon Condensation temperature °C 61
5 Pin Intake pressure MPa 0.35
6 Pout Back pressure MPa 1.75
Table 2
Dimensions of the twin cylinder swash plate compressor
No. Parameter Description Unit Value
1 D Cylinder diameter mm 20
2 L Cylinder length mm 16.5
3 τ Relative clearance volume % 3.125
4 S Piston stroke mm 16
5 Sc Cross-section areas of overflow channel mm2 2.25

sec.title: 4.2 Simulation method
sec.p: The flow field in the swash plate compressor is three-dimensional and is analysed by CFD. The governing equations include the conservation equations of mass, momentum, and energy. A finite-volume approach and the implicit difference method based on pressure are used to solve the governing equations. The second-order upwind scheme is selected to discretize the governing equations, and the SIMPLE algorithm is employed for pressure–velocity coupling.

Flow in the swash plate compressor is complex and turbulent because of the high operation speed. Therefore, the turbulence model is also added to the solution of the equations for swash plate compressor simulation. The Renormalization Group k–ε turbulence model is used in the simulation. This model is a modified representation in equation ε, which enhances the dissipation rate in the vicinity of the stagnation region and effectively prevents the augmentation of turbulent kinetic energy.

The model of the swash plate compressor is meshed with an unstructured grid. The mesh near the overflow channel adopts local mesh refinement to ensure flow field accuracy. The total number of meshes is approximately 220 626, and their minimum and maximum lengths are about 0.134 and 1.27 mm, respectively.

The operation of the swash plate compressor is an unsteady process. The shape and volume of the working cylinders constantly change during the operation. Thus, a dynamic mesh should be used in the simulation of the swash plate compressor. A user-defined function is created to define the movement principle and control piston movement.

Table 3 shows the effect of the time step on the stability of the numerical method in the simulation. According to the results, the value of 0.000 005 s is taken as the time step during the overflow, and it is 0.000 05 s for the other processes in the simulation. Table 3
Effect of the time step on the stability of the numerical method
Overflow process Compression process
Time step (10−6 s) Overflow time (10−4 s) Maximum overflow velocity (m/s) Time step (10−5 s) Duration for compressing the gas to the back pressure (10−2 s)
6 8.33 174 6 1.201
5 8.36 174 5 1.200
4 8.37 174 4 1.200

In accordance with the analysis above, the following boundary conditions are used in the simulation.
Inlet and outlet boundary conditions: The pressure boundary condition is used for the inlet and outlet, and the total and static pressures are determined based on operational conditions.
Wall boundary condition: In this simulation, the contribution of the heat transfer of wall to the change of the internal energy of the gas in compression cylinder is less than 2 per cent; therefore, the effect of heat transfer of wall can be disregarded. No slip boundary condition is used for the internal surface of the cylinder. The piston wall is a moving wall, with a speed of about 1.067 m/s.
Boundary conditions in relation to turbulence: Standard wall functions are used for the turbulence model. Turbulent kinetic energy and the turbulent kinetic energy dissipation rate can be obtained using the following empirical equation
(39)

sec.title: 4.3 Results and discussion
sec.p:
The results of the simulation of the conventional swash plate compressor are shown in Fig. 18. At the initial time, the expansion and compression cylinders function at the end of the exhaust process and at the end of the intake process, respectively. The expansion cylinder initiates the expansion process approximately adiabatically, while another cylinder enters the compression process. The gas pressure in the expansion cylinder reaches the point of intake pressure (0.35 MPa), and the expansion process ends and intake process begins when the time is about 0.001 87 s. The exhaust process of the compression cylinder begins when time is approximately 0.012 02 s and ends when the volume of the compression cylinder reaches a minimum value (0.015 s, at which time, the intake cylinder reach the maximum volume and the intake process ends). According to the analysis above, the intake and exhaust times are about 0.013 13 and 0.002 98 s, respectively. Fig. 18
Variations in the pressure of the conventional swash plate compressor

Figure 19 illustrates the variations in the pressure of the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel. Overflow begins at 0 s and ends at about 0.000 836 s. The pressures in the clearance volume and compression cylinder tremendously change, and the change rate is visibly larger than that of the conventional swash plate compressor (Fig. 18). The beginning times of the intake and exhaust processes are about 0.000 875 and 0.011 805 s, respectively. The corresponding intake and exhaust times are approximately 0.014 125 and 0.003 195 s, respectively. The detailed performance analysis results are shown in Table 4; these findings show that the volumetric efficiency considerably improves from about 90 to 97 per cent, an enhancement by approximately 7 per cent, and the cooling capacity also has been improved by about 7 per cent from 851 to 912 W. The variations in the overflow velocity are shown in Fig. 20, and the maximum value is approximately 174 m/s. Fig. 19
Variations in the pressure of the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel Fig. 20
Variations in the overflow velocity of the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel Table 4
Comparison of the performance of the swash plate compressor with and without an overflow channel
Parameter Unit Swash plate compressor with an overflow channel Conventional swash plate compressor Improvement (%)
Intake time s 0.014 125 0.013 13 7.58
Exhaust time s 0.003 195 0.002 98 7.21
Volumetric efficiency % 97.29 90.66 6.63
Cooling capacity W 912 851 7.21

The comparison of the theoretical analysis and simulation results are shown in Table 5. The overflow time determined from the theoretical analysis is much longer compared with that determined in the simulation results because of the assumption that the clearance and compression cylinder volumes remain unchanged. This results in an average overflow velocity that is larger than that in the simulation. The same factor also generates a higher pressure difference between the compression cylinder and clearance volume after the occurrence of overflow compared with that obtained from the theoretical analysis. The cooling capacities determined from the theoretical and simulation analyses improve by 9.72 and 7.21 per cent, respectively. The relative deviation of the cooling capacities between the theoretical and simulation results is within 5 per cent. Table 5
Comparison of the theoretical and simulation analysis results
Parameter Unit Theoretical analysis Simulation analysis Relative deviation (%)
Overflow time s 0.0011 0.000 836 31.52
Maximum overflow velocity m/s 198 170 13.79
Pressure in the compression cylinder at the end of overflow MPa 0.40 0.41 3.41
Pressure in the clearance volume at the end of overflow MPa 0.40 0.36 10.92
Cooling capacity of the conventional compressor W 869 851 2.09
Cooling capacity of the compressor with an overflow channel W 953 912 4.48
Cooling capacity improvement % 9.72 7.21 2.51

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSION
sec.p: The volumetric efficiency of the swash plate compressor is related only to the compression ratio and the relative clearance volume. The volumetric efficiency continuously decreases with the increase in these two influencing factors. The volumetric efficiency of the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel is visibly better than that of the conventional swash plate compressor. When the compression ratio and the relative clearance volume are in the range [1, 8] and [1%, 15%], respectively, the volumetric efficiency of the swash plate compressor with overflow is kept nearly above 95 per cent.

Aside from the compression ratio and the relative clearance volume, the factors influencing the cylinder displacement also include the dimensions of the swash plate compressor. Under the same dimensions, the cylinder displacement of the compressor has a certain decline with increasing compression ratio and relative clearance volume. The cylinder displacement of the compressor with an overflow channel is noticeably larger compared with that of the conventional compressor.

With the increase in cross-section area of overflow channel, the overflow time and the maximum velocity at the overflow channel gradually declines. The gas pressure and temperature in the compression cylinder continuously increase, whereas the variations in the clearance volume show an opposite trend at the end of overflow. The gas pressure in the compression cylinder is almost higher than that in the clearance volume at the end of overflow, and the pressure difference gradually increases with increasing cross-section of overflow channel.

The comparison of the swash plate compressor with an overflow channel and the conventional unit shows that the intake and exhaust times improve to a great extent after the overflow channel is incorporated into the compressor. This, in turn, considerably enhances the cooling capacity from 869 to 953 W, an improvement by 10 per cent in this article, and the coefficient of performance decreases by about 3.7 per cent.

The cooling capacity of the swash plate compressor with overflow channel is obviously larger than the conventional compressor in terms of the same operation and dimension parameters. The overflow can make the swash plate compressor more compact and lightweight. However, the coefficient of performance of the swash plate compressor with overflow channel has a certain decrease compared with the conventional compressor, moreover, the overflow design will increase the machining difficulty and the controlling complexity.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This study was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 50976067).
